paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses the V30M (p.V50M) mutation in the TTR gene, focusing on its clinical significance and penetrance data in patients with hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis.

patients.demographics: Age 58-75 years, all diagnosed with ATTR V30M
patients.phenotype: Hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis with neurological symptoms

individual_records.evidence_sentence: The neuropathic phenotype with early onset (below the age of 50) is associated with an otherwise rarely found type of transthyretin amyloid.
Five patients with ATTRv showed a pathological Z-score only in the cerebellum (and a non-pathological global composite Z-score).

individual_records.phenotype_details: Neuropathy with transient focal neurological episodes
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Four patients had transient focal neurological episodes (TFNEs) that included speech difficulties or aphasia.

functional_data.summary: The V30M mutation leads to a predominantly neuropathic disease with variable phenotypes.

variants.segregation_data: The V30M mutation segregates with disease in families, as evidenced by the familial occurrence of symptoms.
variants.evidence_level: Strong evidence based on clinical presentation and familial segregation.
variants.additional_notes: The study highlights the importance of age at onset in determining the penetrance of the V30M mutation.
key_quotes: The aggregation, distribution, and neurotoxicity of deposited amyloid species in the brain are well-described for the most common neurodegenerative disorder, Alzheimer's disease.
55% of the patients with ATTRv amyloidosis had an abnormally increased cerebral amyloid burden.

tables_processed.table_caption: Clinical data of the 20 patients with hereditary transthyretin amyloid amyloidosis.

extraction_metadata.notes: The extraction was straightforward as the paper focused on the V30M mutation in the TTR gene.
